Coming together is a beginning, keeping together is progress, working together is success.
Coming together is a beginning, keeping together is progress, working together is success.

Tim is against it for the reason of he is not interested
in learning Python, PHP, or Erlang or other languages.
“Are we scaring away the non-Microsoft developers?”

Starting and Scaling
a Startup Outside of
Silicon Valley
Growing as big as possible as quickly as possible in Portland
Growing as big as possible as quickly as possible in Portland
“You might get developers to move to Portland; no-one wants to move to Tulsa, Oklahoma.”
Some guy who works on pop-up ads

$250,000 for trip planner software with mobile 
phone capability
Seat on City of Tulsa Economic Development Committee
Dozens of Aurora and Nightly users
Making a living is a success.
Forming a connection with another person is a success.

notes.slide-11: I ran Tulsa PHP from 2007 until 2010. Notice we went 8 months between a meeting in January, and the next in October.
notes.slide-12: Josh Mize, a local python developer, ran Tulsa Python from 2008 until 2010. Notice they had a meeting in May, next in September, then again in June. Which brings us to Rule #1:
notes.slide-13: Consistency. At an OSCON “Evolution of Community” panel, I asked how stale open source projects can rejuvenate themselves. They said the most important thing is to consistently make releases. For community, this means consistently have events. People need to know that the group *will* be there, even if it’s just a few people. (James, this is why I sent a terse reply to the possibility of canceling the April Beer & Tell. Sorry about that.)
notes.slide-20: I realized I was “scared” - or at least intimidated - of our developer community in Tulsa. Apart from our irregular PHP meetings, I went to tech conferences that were almost *hostile*, and never felt like I really *belonged* there.
notes.slide-21: So, that evening I decided I would start a great web developer community in Tulsa - where EVERY web developer felt like they belonged. Which brings us to rule #2.
notes.slide-14: In 2010 Brad moved to the Valley to work for Alcatel-Lucent, leaving Tim alone to run the Ruby group.
notes.slide-15: So Tim sent Josh and I an email about an old idea to merge the groups.
notes.slide-22: Don’t be a zealot. When you’re in a town with a small developer community, you can’t afford to bash and intimidate other developers, whether they use .NET, PHP, or even Ruby. Especially new developers in the community - focus on technology and topics that span platforms.
notes.slide-30: Engage other groups. Tulsa School of Dev is dominated by Microsoft & .NET developers, (pretty obvious from their website design, right?) In Oklahoma City, the Red Dirt JavaScript conference is part of a larger innoTech conference. Rather than start a competing conference in Tulsa, we run web tracks at tech events that are already well-established.
notes.slide-16: That was actually MY idea back in 2008. At the time, Brad & Tim didn’t want to combine the groups because they didn’t want to do something outside the cult of Rails.
notes.slide-23: Search is a great example of such a topic. A couple weeks later, at our first combined Tulsa Web Devs meeting, we had 6 people, some pizza, soda, and homebrew. I gave a presentation about rewriting the SourceForge.net search system with Apache Solr.
notes.slide-24: By December, we had a 2nd meeting and a website. Tim had apparently gotten over his fear of non-Ruby languages, so he talked about node.JS. Patrick agreed to do January’s meeting on CSS3. In a web developer group, HTML, CSS, and JavaScript are all great topics that span all the backend platforms.
notes.slide-31: Our web track focused on WordPress - Carlos showed WordPress installation and hosting, Saif showed how to manage a WordPress site, Patrick customized WordPress with themes and plugins, and then I destroyed our Tulsa Web Devs WordPress site thru security exploits. My talk in particular attracted at least 50 attendees, while most other talks had a dozen or so. And that’s Rule #17.
notes.slide-17: Anyway, at the same time, we were all preparing for Tulsa Tech Fest, an annual conference heavily focused on Microsoft and .NET developers.
notes.slide-32: Use the Mozilla effect. The Mozilla brand is very strong in smaller towns. A couple months ago, we brought a bunch of the MDN community - including about 20 Mozilla employees - to New York for a hack day, and we had about 50 non-Mozilla attendees. I had the same number of attendees at my talk at Tulsa Tech Fest, and most of that had to do with the little “Mozilla” after my name on the speakers list.
notes.slide-18: Since we were talking about combining our community, I decided to go to the Community Leadership Town Hall the night before Tulsa Tech Fest.
notes.slide-19: One of the topics proposed at the town hall unconference was, “Are we scaring away the non-Microsoft developers?” but no-one voted on it.
notes.slide-40: found out there’s a limit of 100 replacement captures in python 2.6’s regular expression library! But, they also built ...
notes.slide-26: The first few months of 2011 was our “keep together” phase. We kept up our monthly meetings. We also tried out a lunch meeting - that didn’t work out very well, and we tried a coworking day, which also failed. Our monthly meetings were the consistent core of the group, but nothing else we tried stuck. Which brings us to Rule #3.
notes.slide-27: Go slow and steady. Small towns are like The Shire - change happens slowly, if it happens at all. Tulsa can never have as many tech events as San Francisco or Portland. Try things, but if something isn’t working, drop it and try something else. You can always try it again later. If you go too fast and too hot on too many things, you’ll burn the community out.
notes.slide-34: In June we had an idea - could we put Tulsa Transit routes and schedules up on Google Maps? (Yes, it really doesn’t work in Tulsa.) So we got some local transit data and a bunch of us met up and managed to produce some of the files Google needs. More on this later.
notes.slide-41: a working prototype! They generated enough of the Google Transit Feed Specification files to pass the validator and used the testing tool to display all the stops, routes, and times in an interactive map. Which brings us to Rule #18 ...
notes.slide-35: Around that time, Mozilla Webdev went to Open Source Bridge in Portland. One of the sessions I attended was “Starting and Scaling a Startup Outside of Silicon Valley” by Michael Richardson. I thought the session might have good info for tech startups in towns like Tulsa.
notes.slide-42: Make things. In a small tech community, people quickly meet almost everyone else, so there’s not as much networking incentive as there is in larger cities where you meet new people at every event. So work on projects that unite people towards a common objective, especially local projects. As people work together, they build a shared history full of stories like that Friday night with python regular expressions. It’s important for a healthy group.
notes.slide-28: So we kept getting together once a month - Jeremy talked about Google Analytics in April and Tim talked about Backbone.js in May, by which time he’d apparently forgotten all about Ruby. April was the first meeting I missed (I was out here for an MDN meetup), but by then others were helping to organize the meetings.
notes.slide-43: In August, we hooked up with Fab Lab Tulsa. (Remember Rule #4?)
notes.slide-29: In May we also put together a Web track for Tulsa School of Dev. Which bring us to Rule #4
notes.slide-50: For Tulsa Hackathon, I recruited 5 developers to lead projects for the organizations. And this rule is straight out of Zombieland:
notes.slide-51: Get a Kickass Partner. If you’re the leader of the group, you will do most of the work, especially at first. But you should ask specific people to do specific things that will help the group. If no-one answers, ask again and again if you need to.
notes.slide-37: When someone asked how to attract developers outside of the Valley. Michael said ... I later found out he was one of a few Portland-based employees of Vidoop. Vidoop was a Tulsa web startup that had 40 Tulsa-based employees. Then they hired a few employees in Portland who convinced them to move everyone up there instead. Within a few months, they were bankrupt and fired everyone.
notes.slide-36: Instead he said Urban Airship essentially bent over backwards to get Silicon Valley venture capital up to Portland so they could send billions of mobile push notifications that, as far as I can tell, are the mobile equivalent of pop-up ads.
notes.slide-45: It also means I can web-stream our Mozilla Webdev Beer & Tell days to Tulsa Web Devs coworking days. So Rule #22:
notes.slide-44: Since the lab was a cool place to hang out, we tried coworking there. First we tried Wednesday, but very few people came, so we moved it to Fridays. Now coworking is another consistent core event of the group and lots of ideas for the group come up at our coworking days.
notes.slide-52: The Hackathon was freaking awesome. We opened with each developer pitching their project to recruit a team, and then we split up to work on each project for 24 hours.  We were at Fab Lab from 6pm Friday until about 3am, and then back at 9am Saturday until 6pm.
notes.slide-53: Josh and Patrick added equipment calendars and reservation request features to the Fab Lab website. They finished in a few hours ...
notes.slide-39: So, a few of us dove into the Tulsa Transit project with renewed passion. John, Jeremy, David, Heather, and I got together on a Friday night, and Jeremy and John ...
notes.slide-38: Anyway, that remark hit me pretty hard. That session more than anything has fueled my passion to make Tulsa’s web and tech community something that compels and attracts web developers.
notes.slide-54: ... so Buddy and Zach started another project for a Fab Lab contest system.
notes.slide-47: In October, I went into the *next* Community Leadership Town Hall with a bit of a chip on my shoulder. I had done a tour of local Tulsa developer groups, including Mobile Tulsa, Tulsa Java, and Tulsa .Net, and I knew we went from being developer outcasts a year ago to - no shit - the best developer group in town.
notes.slide-46: Try things again. Coworking didn’t work out for us at first because our first location was bad and we weren’t big enough to have many coworkers. But we kept growing and we got plugged into the Fab Lab, so we tried it again and it worked better the next time.
notes.slide-48: For example, last year we got the main stage at Tulsa Tech Fest - the largest annual tech event in Tulsa. 300 people. Our HTML5 sessions had dozens of attendees and we got lots of audience questions and participation. Now that Microsoft is supporting more and more HTML5, it’s another great topic that spans vendors and platforms. Last month one of the Tulsa Web Devs spoke again about HTML5 at the Tulsa .NET User Group. And next month one of our members is speaking to them again about SignalR and WebSockets.
notes.slide-55: Matt came up from Dallas to lead a “Call or Click” project for INCOG that receives ride requests from an online form or thru a Twilio voice application.
notes.slide-60: Our group made up about 1/3 of the attendees to Startup Weekend Tulsa.
notes.slide-49: We went straight from Tulsa Tech Fest to Fab Lab to start our Tulsa Hackathon a 24-hour event where we hacked on projects for local non-profit and civic organizations.
notes.slide-56: Matt Galloway’s team started an iPhone app for a Tulsa Library’s photo collection. It’s now available in the app store as “Tulsa Then & Now”. (Remember Rule #2) Darren Gibson also started an Android version of the same app.
notes.slide-61: Patrick also created the Magic Grip at Startup Weekend.
notes.slide-57: Kindler and Randall’s Food Bank team made an online availability calendar and volunteer application for the Food Bank.
notes.slide-62: And Buddy helped with the pantryfoo.com team.
notes.slide-63: And Randall and Heather started GavelHound.com
notes.slide-58: John’s Team built Tulsa Road Information Feed - TRIF. It lives at trif.tulsawebdevs.org and aggregates real-time traffic and road closure data from three official sources.
notes.slide-64: After all the excitement of October, November and December were pretty calm for us. Remember Rule #3.
notes.slide-65: If or when you group lots of events and activities, give the community a break for a while. For our December meeting, I gave a “Year in Review” talk - pretty much the same story I’ve told until now.
notes.slide-59: Two weekends after the Hackathon, John also lead a Startup Weekend team that used the TRIF data to build OttoZen - a service that sends you a text message if there’s an accident along your morning commute. (Remember Rules #4 and #18)
notes.slide-66: Also in December, I was invited to speak to the Tulsa Transportation Policy Committee about some of the transportation-related projects we had done with INCOG. Someone mentioned Tulsa Transit had recently bought software for online trip planning similar to Google Maps. So, I asked a research librarian we met at the Hackathon if she could find out how they procured the new trip planning software. Within an hour, she found it cost Two hundred and fifty THOUSAND dollars.
notes.slide-70: So we threw together a Gov 2.0 track for Tulsa School of Dev. (And made them a new logo.) We wanted to teach anyone how to participate in the Hackathon, so we covered git & github and web scraping in python, ruby, and node.js.
notes.slide-67: Oh, and speaking of money, that reminds me - you’ll need to get sponsors. For small stuff, you may be able to just send an expense report to Morgamic. But when your events start costing $1000, you’ll need some official support. And that’s Rule #25:
notes.slide-71: I invited a web developer group from Oklahoma City - thediv.org - to do this year’s web track at School of Dev so we could focus on the gov 2.0 and open data stuff.
notes.slide-72: We had our 2nd Hackathon right after School of Dev. This time we made it 48 hours and only a few of us had well-defined projects going into the Hackathon.
notes.slide-68: Sell annual sponsorships. When you’re organizing events in smaller towns, you don’t have access to a ton of sponsors, so you can’t just email blast a ton of sponsors for each event. I spent dozens of hours getting $1500 of sponsorship for our first Hackathon. What’s better is to make deeper connections with fewer sponsors. So now, we sell annual sponsorships of all our events for $1000-$3000 per year. That way I only have to do a fund-raising push once per year to cover all our events.
notes.slide-73: John came back, starting to package the Google Maps code as a web app so that any city or town could use it. We hope to deploy the app at Code for America Brigade.
notes.slide-74: Jeremy set up a boundary web service api, enhancing an open-source project from newsapps. You input a latitude & longitude to get back your census tract, city district, school district, voting district, local, state and national representatives, and a bunch of other data we found. We may also deploy this to Code for America Brigade.
notes.slide-69: Anyway, the Tulsa Transit price tag inspired me to make the theme for our next Hackathon gov 2.0. To build civic sites and apps using public data sources that enhance our local civic services for free.
notes.slide-75: I started working on a site called WhereYourMouth.is. I scraped the restaurant inspection data from the Tulsa Health Department, geolocated it, and reverse engineered a scoring system so when you are at a restaurant you can look up its latest score.
notes.slide-76: But our 2nd Hackathon was sort of a dud. We only had about 15 people show up this time, and Jeremy was the only one who really finished anything. So we learned a couple Rules from the experience:
notes.slide-77: Stay focused. For example, if you’re a web developer group, don’t do a gov 2.0 event. Especially not gov 2.0. Government is every bit as frustrating to work with as everyone says it is, and unless a bunch of your group members are in government already, you’re going to fight an uphill battle to get any traction or momentum. The other rule is:
notes.slide-81: And here’s some kinda cool facts about the group now.
notes.slide-82:
This is some of the Mozilla-related numbers.

Right now we’re forming some ideas that might turn into new rules in the future.
notes.slide-78: Promote your events. For the second Hackathon, we intentionally did NOT promote the event as much as the first to see if promotion makes a big difference, and it does! In a smaller town, you can’t just put up a website and send a single email blast. You need to invite every other developer group, every company that employs developers, and invite individual developers personally.
notes.slide-83: Since we’ve grown to 150 members, special interest groups are forming - Design, WordPress, and JavaScript in particular. To accommodate the natural growth without splitting up the group, we’re moving our meetings to new event space that will allow us to have up to 3 separate tech talks at every meeting.
notes.slide-84: We’re also focusing on another aspect of Tulsa that’s a bit different from the valley. We’re planning to add children’s events to some of our tech events - thediv.org now has a Div Jr. program, and there’s the Mozilla Hackasaurus program, and we’re thinking about doing a maker faire with kids’ activities.
notes.slide-79: So here’s some of the raw numbers for the group today.
notes.slide-85: I want to close with this quote from Jono of Mozilla Labs. He wrote a great post called, “Let’s hear it for the Long Tail.” The gist of his post is that Silicon Valley has a monomaniacal focus on hugeness - whether it’s numbers of users, amounts of venture capital, number of ad impressions, whatever. But we developers shouldn’t be trapped into this mentality. Instead of quantity, we should define our success by the quality of our lives, our creations, and our connections with others.
notes.slide-1: I want to talk about how to contribute to a web community in your town. Many of us remotes have a somewhat unique position and perspective - we’re employed by the largest open-source web project in the world, but we live and work in some smaller places with small technology communities. Let me show you.
notes.slide-2: Think of events as the pulse of community. Here’s a brief list of tech and web events happening back in San Francisco and the valley this week while we’re in Santa Cruz. (Sorry you’re missing MongoSF, Peter)
notes.slide-3: And it’s not just a valley thing - Portland also has a bunch of tech events going on. It’s a similar story for Toronto, New York, London, Paris - any major city has built-in tech community from its sheer size.
notes.slide-4: Here’s what’s going on back home in Tulsa this week. So, our community is a small community.
notes.slide-5: The only way I know to talk about community is to tell the story of Tulsa Web Devs.
notes.slide-6: But I’ll point out a list of rules we’ve learned along the way that may help you with web communities in your own hometowns.
notes.slide-7: If you want a good book, read The Art of Community by Jono Bacon. Jono spoke at the last Mozilla All-Hands. His blog is about communities the size and scale of Ubuntu and Mozilla, but this book has lots of advice for smaller communities too.
notes.slide-8: {quote} Bacon includes this quote from Henry Ford early on, which I’ve found describes our group really well.
notes.slide-9: In our case, we came together by ending our previous groups.
notes.slide-10: Tim Morgan and Brad Vernon, a couple of Ruby developers, ran Tulsa.rb sporadically from 2007 until 2010.
